Cyclone Ditwah devastates all of Sri Lanka in unprecedented disaster
subhead: Accompanied by torrential rainfall, Cyclone Ditwah triggered landslides and floods that killed at least 410 people, with 336 still missing. President Anura Kumara Dissanayake has issued an appeal for international assistance.
byline: By Sophie Landrin (New Delhi, India, correspondent) and Sandun Jayawardana (Colombo, Sri Lanka, special correspondent)

title: 'Talks with the ECB' on France's debt: What Bardella's uncertain project would entail
subhead: The far-right Rassemblement National party says France could implement a drastic savings plan in exchange for the European Central Bank buying back French debt. The idea has already been rejected within the monetary institution.
byline: By Eric Albert and Clément Guillou

title: Asterix amusement park to open in Germany
subhead: The company operating the Parc Asterix theme park, one of France's largest tourist attractions, announced it would open a sister site in Leipzig, Germany.

title: Marseille grapples with drug trafficking: 'They are so many and they have so much money'
subhead: After the murder of Mehdi Kessaci, the brother of an activist against drug trafficking, Le Monde spoke with residents of housing projects, social workers, judges and police officers. They described a growing sense of powerlessness and danger.
byline: By Grégoire Biseau (Marseille (France) special correspondent) and Gilles Rof (Marseille (France) correspondent)

byline: Interview by Annick Cojean and Vanessa Schneider

title: Mexico's new Frida Kahlo museum bends the truth
subhead: Since opening to the public this fall in Mexico City, a new museum devoted to painter Frida Kahlo has sparked a series of controversies. Contrary to claims by its owners, the house was never the home of the Kahlo family, and a mural discovered on site was likely not the artist's creation.

title: When private anger turns into a social force
subhead: In France, anger is everywhere: in the public sphere, in the media and at the ballot box. The majority of French people under the age of 35 say they have experienced it. From private feelings to collective outcries, they search for ways to channel this emotion.
